passage.text: Involving Crowdworkers with Lived Experience in Content-Development for Push-Based Digital Mental Health Tools: Lessons Learned from Crowdsourcing Mental Health Messages

Digital tools can support individuals managing mental health concerns, but delivering sufficiently engaging content is challenging. This paper seeks to clarify how individuals with mental health concerns can contribute content to improve push-based mental health messaging tools. We recruited crowdworkers with mental health symptoms to evaluate and revise expert-composed content for an automated messaging tool, and to generate new topics and messages. A second wave of crowdworkers evaluated expert and crowdsourced content. Crowdworkers generated topics for messages that had not been prioritized by experts, including self-care, positive thinking, inspiration, relaxation, and reassurance. Peer evaluators rated messages written by experts and peers similarly. Our findings also suggest the importance of personalization, particularly when content adaptation occurs over time as users interact with example messages. These findings demonstrate the potential of crowdsourcing for generating diverse and engaging content for push-based tools, and suggest the need to support users in meaningful content customization.
INTRODUCTION

Mental health conditions are extremely common, particularly major depression and anxiety disorders, with lifetime prevalence rates in the U.S. of approximately 16.6% and 28.8%, respectively. Digital mental health (DMH) tools, such as those delivered through mobile phones and personal computers, have potential to dramatically expand access to support for individuals managing these concerns. However, translating effective support into an engaging digital format presents challenges. DMH tools have historically delivered content from psychotherapy, but navigating this content on one’s own can require significant motivation and effort. While a number of DMH tools have helped users reduce their mental health symptoms in clinical trials, they have largely failed to engage users in real-world settings.

DMH tools best engage users when they fit within daily activities and routines of technology use. Push-based automated messaging tools represent one such approach, leveraging users’ ongoing access to and use of mobile phones throughout the day to deliver a stream of content. In contrast to pull-based approaches, where users browse a menu of possible content or functions and launch interactions with a system when they choose, push-based approaches involve the system initiating interactions with the user, such as by sending information and prompts through texts or notifications. Push-based approaches can help overcome issues like users’ having low motivation or forgetting to use tools, making it more likely that support reaches them in the moments and contexts when they are changing their day-to-day behaviors and routines. However, for push-based messaging tools to inspire positive changes, users must not only receive content, but also read, interpret, and act on it. Yet, typical content-development processes may not produce content that is optimally engaging or actionable. Digital health tools often rely on domain experts to develop content based on therapeutic strategies and behavior change models, but these experts may have gaps in their understanding of users’ day-to-day challenges. They may also struggle to compose messages that are accessible to users, or that match conventions of communication channels like texting.

Human-computer interaction (HCI) approaches have potential to improve the design of DMH tools, and to increase the likelihood that users engage with them over a timeframe sufficient to achieve benefits. In particular, as part of a user-centered design (UCD) process, users’ perspectives can guide development and refinement of the content within DMH tools, allowing for a better match with users’ needs. Past UCD studies have found that users have strong views about appropriate topics and tones of mental health messages. Users also differ from one another in the message types they prefer, suggesting the need to improve messaging tools through personalization. While computational approaches can now be employed to “tailor” content to individuals in sophisticated ways, tailored messaging tools require particularly diverse content from which to draw.

One approach to developing diverse content is through peer production methods such as crowdsourcing. Crowdsourcing has become an established HCI method, and has been applied to generate supportive messages in other mental health contexts, with crowdworkers providing one-to-one support through text chat, and through a system wherein they reframe one another’s negative thoughts. However, crowdsourcing has rarely been used to generate content for push-based messaging tools that deliver mental health content across contexts and over time (e.g., via text messaging). Such systems can provide ongoing and accessible support, but also present challenges. Since content is not linked to a particular user-submitted concern, it can cover highly diverse strategies for managing mental health. There is a need, therefore, to understand which topics most interest potential users, which topics are promising for integrating crowdsourced content, and how to select from a diverse content set to match a particular user’s needs (i.e., personalization). To inform applying crowdsourcing in content-development for push-based automated messaging tools, the present paper asks 4 research questions (RQs). First, we ask what types of mental health messages crowdworkers most commonly compose for a push-based automated messaging tool (RQ1). Next, we ask how a second wave of crowdworkers evaluates messages composed by their peers relative to those composed by experts, including whether there are topics for which experts or peers have relative strength (RQ2). Third, we examine crowdworkers’ perceptions of push-based messaging tools, emphasizing their perspectives on how content within such tools should be personalized (RQ3). Related to this, we finally ask how crowdworkers’ initial evaluations of message topics align with their ratings of specific messages within those topics (RQ4), which may illuminate whether baseline topic selection is a sufficient strategy for personalization.

To address these questions, we conducted a study on Amazon’s Mechanical Turk, involving two waves of crowdworkers with mental health symptoms. The first wave of crowdworkers acted as content creators and the second wave acted as content evaluators and answered open-ended questions about assembling content to be delivered in an automated messaging tool. In this paper, we describe our process of soliciting crowdsourced content, what we learned about utilizing crowdsourcing in a mental health context, and the implications for improving automated messaging tools. Our results show that, through responding to a simple prompt, crowdworkers greatly expanded the set of topics available for automated messaging, introducing self-management strategies as well as emotional support topics that had not been prioritized by experts. Furthermore, crowdsourced messages were rated as highly as expert messages by the second wave of crowdworkers, although experts retained an advantage in composing content in some areas. Finally, our results suggest the importance of personalization, particularly when adaptation of content occurs over time as users interact with example messages.

This study highlights that, in addition to rapidly generating content, crowdsourcing has promise to draw on lived experiences to connect messages more closely to the concerns of end-users. The application of crowdsourced content in push-based automated messaging tools could provide users with ongoing guidance and support from peers without direct interaction, consistent with many users’ preferences to use DMH tools independently.

The rest of the paper is as follows: in the next section, we highlight the related literature on DMH tools, automated messaging, and crowdsourcing. In Section 3, we discuss Wave 1 of the study, detailing our crowdsourcing process and characterizing the content produced (RQ1). In Section 4, we discuss Wave 2, in which peers evaluated this content and shared their views of push-based automated messaging tools (RQ2-RQ4). In Section 5, we discuss the complementary roles that peers and experts could play in content-development, and opportunities for deploying crowdsourced mental health content within automated messaging tools.
RELATED WORK

In the following sections, we describe the related work that motivates this study. We highlight challenges in designing DMH tools that keep users engaged, the potential applications of tailored messaging to this problem, and finally applications of crowdsourcing to DMH.
Digital Mental Health Tools

Mental health conditions are vastly undertreated, with less than half of affected individuals in the US receiving professional help. While treatments like psychotherapy have demonstrated effectiveness for reducing symptoms of depression and anxiety, many individuals face barriers accessing treatment. These include structural barriers like costs and inadequate insurance coverage, as well as attitudinal barriers like low perceived need for treatment.

DMH tools represent one promising method to deliver mental health support for those who cannot access or do not want formal treatment. Many individuals with mental health concerns now express openness to or preference for digital support, citing factors of convenience, affordability, anonymity, self-pacing, reduced stigma concerns, and self-sufficiency. DMH tools appear to be on a trajectory of continued growth, accelerated by the COVID-19 pandemic.

However, currently available DMH tools have yet to deliver on their substantial promise to address mental health issues. A small number of these tools have been rigorously evaluated and shown to reduce symptoms, but these tools have struggled to attract a user base and sustain engagement “in the wild”. Evidence-based DMH tools largely translate treatment elements that are effective in face-to-face therapies, such as strategies from cognitive behavioral therapy. However, translating these elements into an engaging digital format is challenging, particularly since users of DMH tools overwhelmingly prefer brief, simple, and low-burden interactions. The average length of use of DMH tools is extremely short, with only 3.9% of those who download mental health apps still using them 15 days later.

The DMH community increasingly recognizes the importance of designing tools that can sustain engagement. One approach involves offering peer-to-peer or professional “coaching”. By delivering support that responds to users’ specific needs and barriers, coached tools appear to have benefits relative to uncoached ones. Yet, substantial numbers of potential users do not want, cannot afford, or cannot access coaching. There is a need, therefore, to design DMH tools that can respond to user needs and preferences while also being fully automated. The next section reviews how automated messaging tools can provide such personalized support.
Automated Messaging

Automated messaging tools have generated considerable interest in the HCI community as a way to reach individuals within their routine uses of technology. Push-based messaging tools, in particular, leverage individuals’ frequent use of text messaging and other text-based communication channels, and follow conventions of these channels by delivering a stream of content in short, digestible segments. As most people carry and engage with mobile phones throughout the day, automated messaging can provide ongoing help to users as they make and sustain positive changes.

Applications of push-based automated messaging in mental health have taken varied approaches, from boosting motivation between therapy sessions, to promoting awareness of mental health services, to relaying strategies for managing symptoms. Tools also vary in their interactivity, falling on a spectrum from exclusively one-way messaging (from the tool to the user), to “chatbots” and dialogue systems that allow users to reply, imitating interpersonal communication. Users have generally responded positively to automated mental health messaging tools, appreciating that they allow anonymity, fit within routines of phone use, and require little user effort.

However, as with other DMH tools, users may stop engaging with messaging tools or opt to stop receiving messages. Designing acceptable messages can be challenging for mental health concerns, as these concerns manifest in a highly idiographic manner, which shapes how messages are viewed. Studies show that some depressed individuals perceive persuasion attempts as controlling, or reject messages’ perceived “corniness”. Some also object to content that they view as psychotherapy-derived, and may favor “wellness” and “lifestyle” concepts. Other studies have shown that content based on psychotherapy can be acceptable to users, but this may require working with users to ensure that concepts are presented appropriately.

Users also have distinct messaging preferences from one another. Factors such as symptom severity and cultural background can affect which messages users prefer. In addition, users vary in the activities they prefer for self-management (e.g., physical activity vs. socializing), which must be considered to deliver appropriate prompts. Preferred messages can even change over time for the same user, such as when a user wants messages to prompt very small tasks when symptomatic and larger tasks when less symptomatic.

This work all suggests the importance of messaging tools that can match a specific users’ needs (i.e., personalization). In personalized tools, users receive content they perceive to be more relevant, which can increase engagement, information processing, message recall, and behavior change. Such personalization can occur through a user’s purposive customization of a system (e.g., where users select preferred message topics), or through tailoring (e.g., where topics are matched to characteristics of the user). While many personalized systems feature customization and tailoring when users begin using a system, some approaches also allow for ongoing adaptation. For example, reinforcement learning is one form of automated tailoring wherein a user trials a number of content types, and their feedback informs an algorithm that predicts what content will be most successful, and delivers more of it.

While the algorithms to personalize messaging are improving, personalized messaging tools require expansive content that can speak to users’ diverse needs. Yet, traditional expert-led content development processes are time-intensive, and may not fully reflect users’ day-today experiences and challenges. UCD approaches have sought to improve messaging by eliciting users’ perspectives, but studies have generally involved small numbers of individuals who participate in interviews or workshops. In the next section, we explore one potential avenue to improve and diversify the content available for personalized DMH tools by drawing directly on the experiences of those with mental health concerns.
Crowdsourcing

Crowdsourcing involves assigning discrete tasks to a “crowd” of individuals reached through the internet, allowing rapid input from large and diverse samples. Importantly, these samples may include individuals who are not well-represented in lab-based research, such as those with lower mobility, greater stigma concerns, or less motivation. Crowdworkers may also share lived experiences with end-users, such as clinical conditions. In such instances, crowdsourcing gives end-users a voice in the design of digital tools by acting as content creators.

Crowdsourced content has been applied within digital health tools in domains including substance use disorders, diet and physical activity, and smoking cessation. This work finds crowdsourcing to be efficient in terms of time and costs for content-development, and suggests that crowdsourced content can be of high quality. For example, experts largely agreed with crowdsourced diet plans, and found crowdsourced messages promoting physical activity to align with behavior change strategies. Crowdsourced messages were also more effective than expert messages at prompting return visits to a smoking cessation website.

The perspectives of peers are also known to help individuals manage mental health concerns. The history of peer-to-peer mental health support includes in-person and online support groups, and a number of DMH tools likewise facilitate connections between help-seekers and help-givers. Research suggests that DMH tools that offer opportunities for peer-to-peer communication have better user engagement than tools that do not. Yet, despite the benefits of peer support, many individuals with mental health concerns prefer not to discuss these concerns with others. Indeed, the majority of those who access digital peer-to-peer forums are “lurkers” who read content without visibly interacting.

A few tools have therefore been designed to facilitate the exchange of peer messages without direct interaction. Examples include Morris et al.’s Panoply system through which crowdworkers receive training in cognitive restructuring and then are asked to generate new appraisals of help-seekers’ negative thought patterns; these re-appraisals are then delivered by a computer agent. Building on this work, another tool features a computer agent that draws from a corpus of past peer support messages, using machine learning to deliver those predicted to best match a help-seeker’s concern. These examples show the viability of crowdsourcing as a scalable method to generate messages that are engaging and responsive to specific user concerns, extending the availability of support deriving from lived experience without direct interaction between peers.

However, past approaches have largely involved “pull” based tools, with users taking initiative to log into a system or engage an agent to address specific concerns. It thus remains unclear how crowdsourced support could be applied within push-based automated messaging tools that deliver an ongoing stream of messages to individuals over time and across contexts. Since content in push-based tools is not linked to a particular user-submitted concern, it can encompass highly diverse strategies for managing mental health problems. There is a need, therefore, to understand which message topics these tools should prioritize, on which topics crowdworkers can most effectively contribute to content-development, and how content within these tools can be effectively personalized.
Summary

Automated push-based messaging tools reach users via an acceptable and convenient communication medium, providing guidance and encouragement as users take steps to manage mental health concerns. Professionals have traditionally developed content for these messaging tools, but while they have important knowledge of behavior change strategies, they may not satisfy the demands of messaging tools for diverse content that speaks to users’ lived experience. Therefore, we explore the potential to use crowdsourcing to cultivate new message topics and content for push-based automated messaging tools (Wave 1), and we assess crowdworkers’ views of crowdsourced and expert-composed content across topics, and the ways automated systems that might draw on this content in personalized ways (Wave 2).
WAVE 1
Participants

The first wave of crowdworkers was recruited in summer 2019 through Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk). Crowdworkers were invited to participate if they had at least a 95% approval rating for completed MTurk tasks, were in the U.S., reported English fluency, and reported an experience of depression, stress, or anxiety in the past year. The survey also included two measures of mental health symptoms in the past two weeks, the 8-item Patient Health Questionnaire, which assesses symptoms of depression, and the 7-item General Anxiety Disorder measure, which assesses symptoms of anxiety. For example, the PHQ-8 measures symptoms of depression like loss of interest, sleep disturbances, and trouble concentrating, and the GAD-7 measures symptoms of anxiety like irritability, uncontrollable worrying, and restlessness. The PHQ-8 is a shortened version of the PHQ, specifically omitting a question about suicidal ideation. We selected the PHQ-8 since real-time, one-to-one follow-up on suicidal ideation was not feasible in our study design. The PHQ-8 is commonly used in large scale and automated studies, and research suggests it approximates the accuracy of the longer PHQ-9 in identifying depression severity. The standard length of the GAD is 7 items, and the measure was administered in full. For both measures, a score of 10 indicates moderate symptoms and is a common threshold for referral to treatment. Partway through data collection, we added the PHQ-8 to a pre-study screener, allowing us to oversample those with at least moderate depression symptoms and to compose a sample that was more evenly distributed across mild, moderate, and severe symptom levels. Participants were compensated at a rate of $15/hour.

In total, 591 crowdworkers launched the study. Of these, 27 did not meet inclusion criteria and were not invited to proceed beyond the screening questions. An additional 23 exited the study before completing any message editing or crowdsourcing tasks. We also reviewed remaining study records and removed cases where participants provided nonsensical entries in open-ended text fields. For cases that were marginal, an attention check question was reviewed, and those who failed this question were removed; given our focus on the qualitative data and crowdsourcing tasks, those who failed the attention check but provided otherwise intelligible responses were retained. In total, 20 participants were excluded for data quality issues. We also excluded 5 cases where participants completed the study twice (their first record was retained). After data cleaning, our final dataset comprised 516 participants. Demographics for these participants are presented in Table 1.
Ethical/Positionality Statement

The authors had training in HCI, health communication, cognitive psychology, and clinical psychology. This project drew on these backgrounds in designing the study and its initial message stimuli, categorizing crowdsourced messages and topics, and interpreting the data. Clinical psychologist co-authors also provided input into recruitment materials, surveys, and study tasks to minimize the discomfort participants might feel. This included using non-stigmatizing language and offering links to mental health resources on completion of the study and for those not meeting eligibility criteria. To reduce burden associated with repetitive tasks, both study waves involved a mix of tasks, including quantitative rating of messages, open-ended questions, demographic surveys, and message composition. We compensated participants to recognize the expertise and value they bring to the design and content-development process, with the specific amount of compensation (above minimum wage) also being commensurate with the effortful nature of the work. All studies were approved by the IRB at the authors’ institution.
Data Collection

Wave 1 crowdworkers answered survey questions and completed a series of message rating, editing, and writing tasks through the Qualtrics research platform that, in total, took approximately 25 minutes to complete. For the purposes of this study, we focus on activities in which crowdworkers contributed to content-development by editing and giving feedback on expert-composed messages, proposing their own message topics, and composing example messages. Participants proceeded to these activities after first evaluating expert-composed content, modified from an existing mental health messaging app. Expert-composed messages represented five psychological strategies that have demonstrated benefits for depression and anxiety: 1) Positive Activities (or “Behavioral Activation”), 2) Thought Challenging (or “Cognitive Restructuring”), 3) Gratitude, 4) Relationships, and 5) Problem Solving. To keep the burden manageable, each participant rated messages related to a random subset of 2 of the 5 strategies. After reading a short paragraph describing the psychological strategy, participants were asked to rate a total of 8 messages on each of the 2 topics (2 x 8 = 16 messages per crowdworker). They were informed that the messages “were designed to be delivered to you on your mobile phone throughout the day.”

For one randomly selected expert-composed message per topic, participants answered open-ended questions about what they liked about it (“What did you like about this message?”), what they would improve (“What about this message could we improve?”), and were asked to revise it (“Can you give us an idea for how to re-write the message to help motivate someone to practice [this strategy]? You can change as much or as little as you like about the message.”). Completing the 3 prompts took approximately 2 minutes. 454 participants (88%) provided a revision of one expert-composed message, with the remainder declining or providing tangentially related comments (e.g., “n/a” or “I am not a great problem solver so it’s hard to say”). In addition, 406 (79%) revised a second expert-composed message, yielding a corpus of 860 messages, from which we drew the “hybrid” messages evaluated in Wave 2.

At the end of the study, participants were prompted to propose new messages or message topics that could be delivered by an automated messaging program: “Maybe there are types of messages we haven’t even thought about that could be helpful to you. In the box below, please write a message, on any topic at all, that you might like to receive to help you manage stress, anxiety, or depression. Or, tell us what kinds of messages we should focus on creating.” In response to this crowdsourcing prompt, 180 (35%) participants composed one or more messages, 249 (48%) suggested one or more message topics, and 87 (17%) declined or did not respond directly (e.g., “No ideas” or “Mental health is very broad you have to customize it to each person”). Responses to this prompt provided the crowdsourced topics and messages evaluated in Wave 2.
Data Analysis

Analysis of the Wave 1 data involved thematic analysis of participants’ open-ended responses and revisions to expert messages, as well as content analysis of all messages and message topics proposed in the crowdsourcing prompt. As far as the crowdsourced topics and messages, our process was based on Owens et al.. First, two coders became immersed in the data by reading all responses. They then each coded a random subset of 50 topic suggestions, grouping similar suggestions together. For example, the “Affirmation” category encompassed topic suggestions such as “encouraging messages” and “messages that remind me I am capable.” The “Self-care” category encompassed topic suggestions such as “messages about taking care of yourself” and “A self-care or self-focus message would be nice.” The two coders then met to compare and consolidate their codebooks, refining topic definitions to better encompass the data. After agreeing to a codebook, the two coders independently coded all topic suggestions, before meeting to resolve coding discrepancies by consensus. Next, the two coders each reviewed a random subset of 50 crowdsourced messages and assigned them to the best-fitting topic(s). They met to discuss coding discrepancies, adjusting topic definitions to better accommodate example messages. One coder went through all topic suggestions and reassigned them as needed to fit the revised definitions. Both coders then independently assigned all crowdsourced messages to the final topics and then met to adjudicate discrepancies by consensus. This process yielded a set of crowdsourced topics that were each associated with example messages.
Findings
This section addresses RQ1 by characterizing the content contributed by Wave 1 crowdworkers, including the crowdworker-edited messages, topic suggestions, and crowdsourced messages.
Crowdworker-Edited Messages

Table 2 shows examples of how crowdworkers evaluated and edited expert-composed messages. These examples illustrate several themes in how crowdworkers approached the task, including tendencies to add detail and to make language less formal. Illustrating a theme of “Increased Detail,” P335 suggested that the Thought Challenging message should provide more guidance on what to do after noticing a negative automatic thought; P493 provided a rationale for following the Gratitude prompt; and P246 added further specification to the Positive Activities prompt, suggesting the receiver set aside an hour for a positive activity. Illustrating a theme of “Easier Tasks,” P171 thought the Problem Solving prompt was too ambitious, and made it simpler, as well as framing small steps as accomplishments.

Finally, P246 and P387 made edits to the vocabulary used, making it less formal, illustrating a theme of “Informality.” Taken together, these revisions suggest crowdworkers’ desire for specific and informal messages that can stand alone and may help users build motivation for and understanding of the behavior change process. On the other hand, experts may have written shorter, less detailed messages based on understanding that these may fit together within an overall messaging program and build on one another over time. They may also have been aware that increasing specificity can make messages harder to apply across diverse users and contexts (e.g., some users may not have a full hour available to do a positive activity).
Crowdsourced Topics and Messages.

The crowdsourcing task (in which crowdworkers were asked to propose message topics or write new messages) resulted in over 20 unique message topics and 206 new messages, as presented in Table 3. Notably, the three most generative topics (Reassurance, Affirmation, and Inspiration) do not prompt the recipient to take specific action, focusing instead on providing encouragement or support. As one participant described as part of their response to the crowdsourcing prompt, it can be important that messages “are just supportive but don’t expect the reader to do anything (P312). Other popular topics (e.g., Relaxation, Self-care) represent specific strategies for mental health self-management. Many of the “Other” proposed message topics were vague, such that assigning specific messages proved too challenging (e.g., proposing “supportive,” “motivating,” or “cheerful” messages).

These data also reveal that the level of explicit interest in message topics (i.e., how frequently topics were proposed) was not strictly correlated with the number of crowdsourced messages that topic generated. For example, only nine crowdworkers suggested that messages should prompt Positive Thinking, but 21 crowdsourced messages fit within this topic. On the other hand, Anxiety Management, Goal-setting/Commitment, and Religious/Spiritual messages were relatively popular topic suggestions, but few crowdworkers wrote messages illustrating these.
WAVE 2
Participants

The second study wave was recruited in summer 2020. As with Wave 1, crowdworkers were recruited through MTurk and eligible if they had at least a 95% approval rating for completed MTurk tasks, were in the U.S., reported English fluency, and reported experiencing depression, stress, or anxiety in the past year. They were also compensated at a rate of $15/hour.

A screening survey was used to assess if potential participants met inclusion criteria, after which 365 participants commenced the study. As with Wave 1, data were reviewed for quality and completeness. This led to excluding 43 participants who did not have sufficient data for analysis, defined as: completing a message topic ranking task, rating messages on each topic, and answering at least one open-ended question. In addition, 13 participants were excluded who provided nonsensical or uninterpretable responses to open-ended questions. This left a final sample of 309 participants. Their demographics are presented in Table 1.
Stimuli Construction

From the topics introduced by crowdworkers in Wave 1, a subset was selected for evaluation in Wave 2 based on crowdworkers having generated the most example messages, suggesting feasibility for future crowdsourcing. We selected 6 crowd-introduced topics for evaluation in Wave 2: 1) Reassurance, 2) Affirmation, 3) Inspiration, 4) Relaxation, 5) Self-care, and 6) Positive Thinking. Descriptions and example messages for the 5 original expert-introduced topics and 6 crowd-introduced topics are in Table 4.

For each of these 11 topics, we created 7 unique message sets, drawing from the available expert, hybrid, and crowdsourced content from Wave 1. Including multiple message sets reduced the bias introduced by nuances of individual messages. Expert messages were randomly selected from the stimuli used in Wave 1. For the hybrid messages, we drew content from the task where crowdworkers revised expert messages. After excluding messages that did not substantively change the original expert messages (i.e., where crowdworkers copied over the original messages or changed one or two words) or where revisions made the connection to the original topic unclear, hybrid messages on each topic were randomly selected (hybrid stimuli are in Table 2). For the 5 expert-introduced message topics, 2 messages came from the original expert-composed message set, 4 were composed by crowdworkers in Wave 1, and 1 was a hybrid message. For the 6 crowdsourced topics, all messages were written by Wave 1 crowdworkers. Following de Vries et al., we focused on the crowdsourced messages that fit most clearly within a topic. Therefore, we excluded messages that belonged to multiple topics. A coder additionally reviewed remaining messages to remove edge cases that seemed ambiguously connected to their topic. Subsequently, the crowdsourced messages were selected randomly.

Crowdsourced and hybrid messages were lightly edited to correct spelling and grammar, as needed, since this can establish credibility and improve message acceptance. For example, one crowdsourced Relaxation message originally read, “Close your eyes, and breathe slowly, focus on your breath, exhale all your negative feelings with every breath” (P167). The lightly edited version corrected a comma splice and capitalization error, reading, “Close your eyes, and breathe slowly. Focus on your breath. Exhale all your negative feelings with every breath” It was also important to follow conventions that text messages be short, so lengthy messages were shortened to 280 characters or less. This process included splitting long messages into multiple messages and removing redundancies. Crowdsourced messages were not otherwise changed.
Data Collection

Participants in Wave 2 completed a series of activities, including message rating, writing tasks, and answering demographic and open-ended survey questions through the Qualtrics research platform. The entire study took approximately 20 minutes to complete. We focus on a subset of the study tasks and questions relevant to answering our research questions.

First, participants were asked to rank their interest in 11 message topics, comprising the 5 expert-introduced topics and 6 crowd-introduced topics, based on a brief description of each topic (see Table 4 for topic descriptions). The instructions read, “Please drag ALL of the types of text messages listed below to rank them according to your interest in receiving them as part of an automated text messaging program for mood and mental health (1=most interested, 11=least interested).” All participants completed this task, which took 2 minutes on average.

Participants next evaluated specific examples of crowdsourced, expert, and hybrid messages on these 11 topics. Participants were randomly assigned to one of 7 message sets, with each set including 1 message per topic (11 topics x 7 message sets = 77 unique messages). Participants rated each message according to their interest in receiving it as part of an automated messaging program (“Imagine you signed up for an automated text messaging program to help with mood and mental health. How interested would you be in receiving each of the following text messages?”). Responses were reported on a Likert scale from 1 (not at all interested) to 7 (extremely interested). All participants completed this task, which was not timed.

Wave 2 participants answered additional survey questions. Immediately after the ranking and rating tasks, participants were asked to elaborate on why they had selected their most and least-preferred topics (e.g., “You were pretty interested in receiving Reassuring messages. Reassuring messages help remind you that facing challenges is normal, and that things are going to be okay or that they are not so bad as they might seem. What are some reasons you’re interested in reassuring messages? What do you like about them?”). Additional open-ended questions asked participants to elaborate on their reasons for interest or disinterest in an automated messaging tool for managing mental health, ways we could design such a tool to meet their needs, and perspectives on personalization of content within such a tool.
Analyses
To assess whether message ratings were different across 3 author types (expert, crowdworker, or hybrid), we employed linear mixed effects models with a random intercept for each participant.

To analyze the qualitative data (i.e., responses to open-ended survey questions), we followed a thematic analysis approach, where two coders first reviewed all responses to develop familiarity with the data. They then independently performed open coding, extracting preliminary themes in how participants perceived message topics, automated messaging tools, and means of personalizing these tools. The two coders each developed an initial codebook, then met to discuss and refine codes, resulting in a shared codebook. In an iterative process, both coders applied the codebook to a subset of data, compared their results, and refined the codebook to better encompass the data. This was repeated until coding new data failed to yield revisions to the codebook, and coders agreed on application of the codes. The data were then divided between the coders, and the final codebook was applied.
Finally, we conducted paired-samples correlations to compare participants’ initial rankings for each topic to their evaluations of example messages within those topics.
Findings

This section describes Wave 2 crowdworkers’ evaluations of crowdsourced and expert generated content, including differences across topics (RQ2), and their views of automated messaging tools, emphasizing approaches to content personalization (RQ3). Finally, we compare initial perceptions of message topics to assessments of example messages on those topics (RQ4).
Comparison of Messages by Experts, Hybrid Authors, and Crowdworkers.

To address RQ2, we first assessed whether message authors (expert, hybrid, or crowdworker) were associated with differences in message ratings, employing a linear mixed effects model, with a random intercept for participants. Message author was entered as a fixed effect. The results revealed that the effect of author on message ratings was not statistically significant (p =.11). Mean ratings for expert-written, hybrid, and crowdsourced messages were 4.65, 4.50, and 4.49, respectively.

Next, we examined whether experts or crowdworkers wrote more acceptable messages on particular topics. We excluded hybrid messages due to their small sample size (one example message per topic). We added a fixed effect for message topic, and an interaction term (author x topic) to our model. Results revealed a significant interaction (p =.01). Bonferroni-adjusted pairwise comparisons revealed that expert-composed messages were rated significantly higher than crowdsourced messages for the “Positive Activities” topic (5.24 vs. 4.46, p =.001; see Fig. 1).

To understand how expert-composed and crowdsourced “Positive Activities” messages differed, we reviewed the message stimuli, which revealed that crowdworkers tended to promote specific, immediate behaviors (e.g., going outside, listening to happy music), whereas experts’ messages were less specific, prompting receivers to identify or schedule activities that they would personally find rewarding (e.g., “Doing more positive activities can make you feel better. To get started, you could schedule one pleasant thing to do tomorrow and pick the time to do it.”). Thus, experts may have better anticipated and accommodated the idiosyncrasy of activity preferences, whereas crowdworkers likely relied on personal experience and preferences.
Interest in Automated and Personalized Messaging Tools.

To address RQ3, we examined survey responses related to perceptions of push-based messaging systems, and means of personalizing these systems. First, when asked to rate their interest in “signing up for an automated texting program, which sends you text messages to help with your mood and mental health,” all 309 participants responded, and they expressed moderate interest, on average, although there was considerable variability (Mean: 50.78 out of 100, SD=29.98). Those reporting interest levels below the midpoint (N=133) were asked the reasons for their disinterest. These responses (average length: 33 words) revealed that perceiving automated messaging as impersonal was the most common reservation (N=57, 43%), with many comparing it unfavorably to human contact, e.g., “I would want… message[s] from a real person. It feels more legitimate and meaningful. It feels false and robotic coming out of a machine” (P82). This was followed by concerns that messaging would be intrusive or annoying (N=27, 20%), e.g., “I worry that I would get annoyed with the messages and treat them as spam” (P77), and then by skepticism that content could be sufficiently relevant or helpful (N=24, 18%), e.g., “I do not see how an automated system can know what to send me that is relevant” (P101). Less commonly cited reasons for disinterest included privacy concerns, limited use of texting/mobile phones, and aversion to texting/mobile phones.

In response to an optional, open-ended question about how to design an automated messaging system (“Do you have any additional thoughts about how we should design an automated program that sends messages about mental health?”), 74 participants responded (average length: 30 words), with many emphasizing that potential drawbacks of such a system could be overcome if messaging were appropriately personalized. One participant noted that, “Messages are different for every person… For example, I like positive upbeat messages but my friend might prefer messages that just say directions with no real emotions in them” (P46). Other participants likewise described that, “there is not one formula that works for everyone” (P44) and cautioned that a successful system “cannot be a one size fits all type of approach” (P223).

Finally, 254 participants responded to the question “Please tell us how you would feel about customizing an automated messaging program so that it is personalized for you” (average length: 25 words), with their responses revealing a prevailing desire to be actively involved in determining how a system is personalized. Of respondents, 211 (83%) affirmed they were interested in customizing a messaging system, 22 (9%) were not interested, and 21 (8%) indicated they were not sure or had no preference. Some also specified elements of messaging they envisioned customizing, generally mentioning topics and scheduling (e.g., time of day, frequency). A few also proposed generating their own content to be delivered by the system (e.g., “allow them to develop their own messages”; P252). Participants largely envisioned relaying these preferences through a survey or customization menu, e.g., “the user can select each of the previously mentioned types of messages” (P12).
Topic Rankings and Message Ratings.

To evaluate how well topic names and descriptions gave an accurate perception of message content, we next compared how participants initially ranked the 11 topics, and their later assessment of actual messages within these categories (RQ4). A high correlation might suggest that potential users have a good understanding of the topics to which they will respond most favorably, whereas a low correlation might suggest users need more information or support to understand the available topic offerings. Fig. 2 shows the average ranking for each topic, based on its brief description only, and the average rating of messages on that topic. Rankings were reversed so their direction was the same as for ratings. Our analysis found that rankings and ratings for the 11 topics were not significantly correlated, r(11)= −.42, p =.19. The largest discrepancy was for the “Self-care” topic, which was ranked second highest based on its brief description, but lowest based on example messages.1 Conversely, the “Relationships” topic was ranked lowest, but message ratings were moderately high.

We also calculated paired-samples correlations to assess whether an individual crowdworker’s initial topic ranking was associated with their rating of an example message for that topic. We found that topic rankings were positively correlated with evaluations of example content for only 5 of 11 topics, with these correlations being small to moderate for: Gratitude, r(307) =.30, p <.001; Inspiration, r(306) =.23, p <.001; Positive Activities, r(307) =.12, p =.03; Positive Thinking, r(307) =.25, p <.001; and Self-care r(305) = .12, p =.03. For the 6 remaining topics, crowdworkers’ topic rankings were not correlated with their message ratings: Affirmation, r(306) =.05, p =.34; Thought Challenging, r(307) =.11, p =.054; Problem Solving, r(307) =−.01, p=.89; Reassurance, r(307) =.04, p=.51; Relationships, r(307) = .04, p=.52; and Relaxation, r(306) =.09, p =.11. This may suggest areas where topic names or descriptions were unclear, or where participants had preconceived notions about these topics.

The qualitative data also suggest challenges that participants might face in customizing content at baseline. After completing the ranking and rating tasks, participants were asked to elaborate on why they favored their highest ranked topic (completed by 306 participants; average length: 42 words) and disfavored their lowest-ranked topic (completed by 303 participants; average length: 35 words). In these responses, several participants seemed to reconsider their earlier rankings. One wrote, “It was kind of vague on what the “Relationships” messages would be about, so I placed them lower” (P142). Another reflected on “Reassurance” messages, which she had ranked lowest: “I don’t necessarily dislike them. I’m not sure why I reacted that way” (P186). Another participant described how the experience of rating messages led to broadly reassessing their perspectives of automated messaging, writing, “I started out this survey thinking I really wouldn’t want to receive text messages about my mental health stuff. But what I had in mind was stuff like gratitude and inspirational type messages… I actually really liked some of the other types of messages that came up (P58).” Thus, greater experience with content could lead to reevaluation of particular topics as well as automated messaging as a whole.

In the same responses, participants also recognized that customization might not guide them to content that was challenging or relevant due to avoidance. For instance, one participant explained that they had ranked “Problem Solving” messages lowest because “I do not like to have to use my brain when I am feeling down (P7). Another participant said of “Thought Challenging” messages, “I’m probably least interested because they’re honestly a weak point of mine so I would rather not be confronted with them” (P45). Similarly, on the topic of “Relationships” messages, another stated, “my relationships are not in a good place and I wouldn’t want to be reminded of them” (P78). Thus, message preferences did not strictly reflect assessments of likely usefulness, but also the effort participants were willing to exert and their comfort level.

Many message types were viewed to have variable utility, depending on the context. For example, one participant stated that they did not generally need “Relationships” messages because they were managing their relationships well, but acknowledged that these might be useful “if I were hurt by or fighting with a significant other or friend” (P150). Another strongly disliked “affirmation messages,” but noted that they might be helpful “when I’m making headway on getting somewhere or getting close to a solution to a problem… I would accept that kind of message to give me a little push across the finish line” (P98). Thus, participants described that even their least preferred message topic could be helpful in a narrow context.

Some also explicitly recognized the value of retaining diversity in the content delivered by a messaging tool, such as a participant who wrote, “I think there is room for formal and informal messages, passive and active messages, humorous and serious messages” (P12). Another said, “I kind of like the automated texting idea as long as it is varied enough” (P3), suggesting that, while potential users may have preferences between topics, novelty also plays a key role in maintaining engagement.
DISCUSSION

Automated messaging has potential to engage users in managing their mental health concerns, but content must evolve to better meet users’ needs. This study highlights the potential of crowdsourcing as part of the content-development process for automated mental health messaging tools, yielding user-friendly content that covers diverse topics, including a number that had not previously been considered in the expert-designed content set. After being exposed to example content from experts, crowdworkers were able to produce messages on the same topics that received similar evaluations as expert-composed messages from a subsequent wave of crowdworkers. In this discussion, we first explore the complementary roles that crowdworkers and experts might play in developing content. We then consider implications of our results for designing personalized automated messaging tools that draw on crowdsourced content.
Generating Mental Health Content through Crowdsourcing

In this section, we discuss the ways in which crowdworkers’ contributions expanded the diversity of topics in our message set, speaking to content areas that may be overlooked by experts but valued by potential users. Our results also clarify the relative strengths of crowdworkers and experts in generating content on specific topics. We discuss the roles that experts could play alongside crowdworkers in content creation, and in categorization of crowdsourced messages.
The Role of Crowdworkers: Discovering Diverse Message Topics.

Our results show that crowdworkers introduced a number of topics that were not captured in the original expert-designed message set and that may be promising to include in future automated messaging tools, largely tapping into crowdworkers’ interest in popular self-help strategies and emotional support. Encouragingly, we found that crowdworkers generally endorsed established strategies for managing mood and mental health. This is consistent with work in the exercise domain where crowdsourced messages relayed evidence-based behavior change strategies. In particular, many participants in our study developed or endorsed content supporting positive thinking, relaxation, and self-care strategies that have become broadly popular as “self-help”, and that can be effective for managing less severe mental health concerns. Crowdworkers’ enthusiasm likely reflects that these strategies are easy to learn and implement, and is also consistent with preferences for content that adopts a general “wellness” focus, versus being explicitly associated with a psychotherapeutic approach. While positive thinking, relaxation, and self-care messages were not in our original expert-composed message set, these strategies have been used in other DMH tools, including a number of commercial apps. Thus, crowdsourcing may be a pathway to integrating content that is highly accessible to end-users, while also reflecting established self-management strategies. This finding is encouraging given that some past work has raised concerns regarding the quality of peers’ mental health support, including potential that peer suggestions will not be supported by evidence.

Crowdworkers also frequently endorsed or composed messages that conveyed support and encouragement without promoting a specific action. Indeed, this described the three topics on which crowdworkers generated the most content (i.e., Affirmation, Reassurance, and Inspiration). In the social support literature, such messages can be considered “emotional support,” because they seek to meet receivers’ emotional needs by making them feel cared for, eliciting positive emotions, or building self-esteem. Crowdworkers’ emphasis on emotional support is also consistent with past studies in which individuals with mental health concerns have endorsed automated messages that affirm and validate their emotions. While many DMH tools primarily use messaging to provide guidance, reminders, and prompts related to specific behavioral strategies, a few have also placed emphasis on emotional support, including a number of “chatbots” and relational agents that seek to develop a positive relationship with the user. Notably, despite participants’ interest in emotional support, few expressed that they wanted explicitly conversational messages, such as those that make small talk or provide companionship. Our results suggest, overall, that emotional support is viewed as highly desirable, even when coming from an automated messaging tool, and may not require imitating interpersonal communication.

Taken together, crowdsourcing can diversify the self-management and emotional support strategies that a messaging tool can deliver, including encompassing content areas that experts might overlook. Consistent with past work highlighting crowdsourcing’s efficiency, hundreds of messages were collected over several days, which is rapid relative to expert-led content development. However, as the next section describes, there likely remain important roles that experts should play alongside crowdworkers when developing content and integrating it within a messaging tool.
The Role of Professionals: Curation and Integration.

Both crowdworkers and experts can play constructive roles in developing content for messaging tools, and our findings provide some guidance on how they can interact, and what their roles should be. First, it is important to note that experts’ messages outperformed crowdsourced messages in some areas, particularly the “Positive Activities” topic. This finding may reflect that this topic relates to a therapeutic approach called Behavioral Activation, which prompts individuals to engage in rewarding behaviors and activities. Knowledge of Behavioral Activation as a therapeutic approach guided experts’ message composition and appears to have been helpful in scoping messages so they were general enough to apply to a wide audience, while also being specific enough to be actionable. This suggests that, moving forward, it could be important for experts to continue to generate content alongside crowdworkers, drawing on nuanced knowledge of behavior change strategies. While not examined here, it is also worth exploring how experts could iterate on crowdsourced suggestions, perhaps revising crowdsourced messages to be more consistent with behavior change strategies or generating new messages on topics proposed by crowdworkers. For example, crowdworkers expressed high levels of interest in messages relating to goal-setting and anxiety management, but few composed example messages on these topics, which suggests that such message types might be especially challenging for laypeople to write.

The role of experts may also include categorizing and curating crowdsourced messages to make use of them within an automated tool. In this study, we coded all crowdsourced messages by topic to describe the nature of this content, but coding also has practical functions when deploying content in automated tools. First, categorizing content allows for testing how message types differentially predict user engagement and outcomes. Second, categorizing content can facilitate automated message tailoring, as tailoring links particular classes of messages to aspects of the user and his/her context. For instance, the value of Behavioral Activation may depend on depression severity, which could translate into a decision rule wherein those with more symptoms are more likely to receive these messages. Thus, in tailored systems, experts draw on their understanding of behavior change strategies to place crowdsourced content within taxonomies that allow for matching it to relevant user-level or context-level variables. Experts may also have insight into the ordering of messages, or which messages are coherent to deliver together. For example, it may be overwhelming or confusing to introduce numerous behavioral strategies too quickly (e.g., prompting Self-care, Thought Challenging, and Positive Activities within the same day), whereas a single strategy could be well-received alongside emotional support messages. Finally, reviewing and categorizing crowdsourced messaging may provide an opportunity to remove unsafe or abusive content.

In sum, an approach where both crowdworkers and experts contribute content, and potentially evaluate and iterate on one another’s contributions, has promise for generating diverse and accessible content, while maintaining quality. To the extent that content is categorized according to relevant message dimensions, messaging tools can also draw on this content to support individuals in highly personalized ways, as we describe in the next section.
Implications for system design

While numerous DMH tools draw on peer-to-peer support, this support is generally delivered when users seek it out rather than being “pushed” to users via automated messaging. In this section, we highlight insights from this study regarding design of automated mental health messaging tools that draw on crowdsourced content, emphasizing participants’ views that messaging must be highly personalized to meet their needs. We then discuss how designers can better support users in customizing content within a messaging tool.
The Importance of Personalization.

Past work in a number of health domains has shown that there are pitfalls in delivering content that is too generic, with users wanting messages to match their individualized needs and preferences. Similarly, our study found that participants were concerned that messages would not match their needs; messages were either considered too generic, or so specific that they would be unusable, especially since needs were widely recognized to fluctuate across contexts. Skepticism that messaging tools can deliver adequate personalization may in part reflect the realities of the messaging tools to which most people have been exposed, which overwhelmingly deliver one-size-fits-all content.

In recent years, computer-tailoring has advanced such that content has potential to be more highly personalized. Whereas early tailored systems delivered content matching only a few user characteristics, data-driven tailoring approaches can take into account many user characteristics, behaviors, and contexts. These approaches include just-in time adaptive interventions that alter the content or timing of messages based on data about a user’s context or behavior; reinforcement learning approaches, where a user’s responses to content (e.g., ratings) are used to optimize future content selections; and recommendation systems, where dimensions of a user’s circumstances are used to select related content, such as delivering past peer responses that may be relevant to a user’s present concerns. Personalization can also occur manually, through customization, when users explicitly choose between content options available to them. While more effortful, customization may nonetheless be desirable in that it provides more direct control over one’s own experience.

Our results revealed that participants were highly interested in customization as a means of making a messaging system more personalized, including wanting to select preferred message topics. Their emphasis on customization over tailoring may reflect that participants lacked awareness of the possibilities for automated tailoring. However, past work has also highlighted that maintaining a sense of control or autonomy is highly important to users when interacting with DMH tools. As the next section explores, a core design question for personalized DMH tools is how to provide autonomy while still ensuring users receive content that supports an effective therapeutic process.
Supporting Meaningful Customization.

Despite the stated importance of customization, our data suggest that participants initially struggled to define their content preferences. Specifically, they initially ranked message topics based on short descriptions, but these rankings were weakly correlated with later ratings of messages on the same topics. Upon reviewing specific messages, some individuals reported finding unexpected value in topics they initially disregarded, and many could also identify contexts where even their least-favored message topics might be useful to them. These findings suggests that users had preconceived notions about topics based on their names and brief descriptions, and these did not always match the actual content (for topics such as Relationships, Thought Challenging, Reassurance, etc.). For example, participants may have assumed the Relationships topic centered on romantic relationships (as some responses indicated), when in fact it was more general. These findings speak to the importance of pre-testing messages, and working with users to understand how they make sense of topic names and descriptions, especially when these are offered in the context of system customization. Another implication of these findings is that prompting users to select between topics too early in using a messaging tool, or based on limited information, could preclude exposure to content with potential to exceed users’ expectations. Some participants also reported that they would avoid topics that are highly relevant if they perceive them as too challenging or unpleasant. Past work has also highlighted the tension between what users say they want, and what actually benefits them, including some work that showed worse outcomes when individuals chose to override system-generated recommendations for stress-management activities and supplant their own choices.

As messaging tools draw on diverse content, it will be important to satisfy users’ desires for choice while also ensuring that content will benefit them. These two design objectives need not be in conflict. For example, a substantial body of work highlights that individuals are more satisfied with decision-making when they feel competent to make choices. Yet, participants in this study likely lacked the information and experience they needed to proficiently weigh content offerings. System design could facilitate more thoughtful and informed content selections in numerous ways, such as by reducing the number of options shown to a user at any one time, providing example content on each topic, or rolling out customization options over time, such that increasingly consequential decisions are made based on experience and knowledge. Exposure to diverse messaging could also be made more acceptable through how the user experience is framed. For instance, “self-experimentation” may be a useful concept, centering the process of exploring and evaluating diverse content, while also highlighting the agency of the participant.

Finding an appropriate balance between message topics may also be an important way that a system can engage users to grow their therapeutic skillset and challenge themselves. In psychotherapy, a “therapeutic alliance” between client and therapist offers a foundation for experimentation with new perspectives and strategies. When using automated tools without such an alliance, users can more easily disengage if content falls outside their comfort zone. Such a limitation can potentially be overcome through designing messaging tools to balance new or challenging content with other content that is lighter, simpler to act on, or more consistent with users’ existing strengths. For instance, more challenging self-management strategies could be introduced slowly, once buy-in is established, and presented alongside emotional support.
Limitations

This study has limitations to consider when interpreting these results. First, our results comparing crowdsourced and expert contributions must be interpreted in light of the specific crowdsourcing process we deployed. While Wave 1 crowdworkers were not trained to deliver peer support, they screened into the study on the basis of high-quality past work on MTurk, and messages were solicited after they were exposed to descriptions of psychological strategies and example content by experts. Furthermore, to reduce burden, participants had a choice of whether to create specific messages or propose desired topics. Crowdworkers who self-selected into message composition may differ from other crowdworkers, perhaps being more engaged or confident in their writing. After composition, messages were also selected from the more promising topics, and lightly edited. Thus, while our results show the value of crowdsourced content, an important caveat is that this content was developed with guidance and curation. In addition, experts only produced content within the five original message topics and did not generate content on crowd-introduced message topics (e.g., experts did not produce “Self-care” messages). Therefore, crowdworkers and experts could have differential strength in these and other content areas. Since we only evaluated a limited sample of hybrid content, we also do not know if there are topics where such content might outperform content from crowdworkers or experts, potentially combining strengths of both parties. An additional limitation is the representativeness of the sample as far as characteristics like race, nationality, and socio-economic status. For example, most of our participants are White and have completed at least some college. For digital tools to have equitable impact, it is important to assess whether and how crowdsourced content and user perspectives vary across populations, and to consider how messaging programs may need to be designed, tailored, and disseminated to reach and benefit diverse populations. Finally, the ratings examined in this study reflect participants’ interest in given messages and topics, but do not capture the usefulness of content in engaging users in day-to-day life or producing improvements in mental health symptoms. There may be content that users benefit from without finding it compelling in the moment, and vice versa. Crowdworkers and experts also may have differing abilities to produce content that ultimately achieves impact on longer-term outcomes like mental health symptoms.
Directions for Future Research

Several questions remain unresolved and should be addressed in future work. Below, we highlight the need to understand how crowdworkers are impacted by creating content, to understand experts’ perspectives on the strengths and weaknesses of crowdsourced content, to clarify how crowdsourced messages should be attributed when deployed in automated messaging tools, and to better understand how the experience of composing and receiving crowdsourced messages may vary based on symptom levels.

First, when applying crowdsourcing in the future, it will be important to better understand crowdworkers’ experiences of generating content. Some past work has considered message composition a particularly effortful and taxing task for crowdworkers. Yet, some participants volunteered that they found the experience rewarding, potentially consistent with the wellbeing benefits of altruism or the potential to work through one’s own problems indirectly by helping others. Future work could therefore examine the motivations and gratifications behind composing mental health messages for peers. Such work may also consider whether editing others’ content (e.g., when crowdworkers edited expert messages to produce hybrid content) may provide a low-burden way to engage in the content creation relative to producing messages de novo, allowing users to contribute their preferred phrasing and framing while building on others’ expertise. Broadly, if crowdsourcing has value to message writers/editors and not just receivers, writing and editing tasks could be supported directly through an automated messaging tool, such as by sending text messages that ask users to reply with their own ideas for or iterations of messages to benefit themselves or others.

Second, this study drew on the expertise of psychologists and HCI researchers to shape the initial message set and to review crowdsourced contributions. Future research might build on this by systematically gathering experts’ evaluations of crowdsourced content. For example, past research has featured an expert panel who gave input on crowdsourced suicide prevention content. Our analysis suggests that many crowdsourced messages reflect established self-help and emotional support strategies, speaking broadly to the suitability of crowdsourced content. However, experts could assess whether individual messages are consistent or inconsistent with the evidence base for specific strategies.

Third, crowdworkers’ evaluations of individual messages in this study were based solely on content, as messages were not attributed to peers, experts, or others. Future research might explore whether revealing messages’ authors could change message reception. Past work suggests that support from peers can allow for an experience of normalization of stigmatized concerns, and may feel “genuine” relative to support from professionals. In addition, those with depression can benefit from awareness of others even when they do not directly interact. It is possible that attributing content to others may provide a “diffuse sociality”, allowing users to feel connected to others without the burden of direct interaction. One past experiment attributed messages either to peers or to an automated computer program, and found higher ratings when the same messages were presented as coming from peers, but these methods have not assessed mental health messages attributed to peers versus experts. More broadly, the reception of messages is likely to be shaped by the ways messages are integrated within a cohesive messaging system, including decisions around attribution, ordering of content, timing, and frequency.

Finally, we do not know how crowdworkers’ symptom levels might shape the ways they compose and evaluate messages. Future work may examine this issue and—if there are meaningful differences in the content that engages users with higher and lower levels of symptoms—it could be helpful to “match” the symptom levels of writers and receiver.
CONCLUSION

Demands for scalable DMH tools, and consumers’ preferences for self-reliance and convenience, point toward the importance of push-based automated messaging. Yet, to have an impact on mental health, push-based messaging tools must deliver content that can reliably garner and maintain diverse users’ attention and interest. Our results suggest that crowdsourcing provides a viable avenue to develop accessible content from which these tools can draw, with crowdworkers introducing a number of new topics and composing messages which were rated similarly as expert messages by their peers. Integrating crowdsourced content into push-based messaging tools may allow ongoing access to peers’ experiences and support without direct interaction. Future work is needed to examine how crowdsourced content can best be integrated into messaging tools, and to test whether integration of this content helps users engage productively with a messaging tool to achieve improvements in mental health symptoms.

Several participants noted concerns that the “Self-care” example messages prompted idiosyncratic behaviors (e.g., “Put away one dish” or “Brush your teeth and hair and you might feel better about yourself”). As P27 described, “I felt these messages… are more encouraging for someone who is having trouble finding reasons to do anything in the morning. I am not a member of this audience”. P101 echoed, “I’m already getting things done like brushing my teeth and hair. I don’t need to be reminded.” The high level of specificity of self-care messages may help explain why they were rated lowest of the messages examined.

Crowd-Edited Messages

passage.infon:
Message Topic Original Expert-composed Message What could be improved? Crowdworker-edited message (i.e., Wave 2 “Hybrid” message)
Thought Challenging Paying attention to how you think about stressful situations can help you feel better. Today, pay attention to your negative automatic thoughts as they arise. The advice here seems a little unclear - it’s telling me to pay attention to my negative thoughts…but not much else? It needs a better explanation of what I’m supposed to do when I pay attention to the negative thoughts, and how I’m supposed to reduce my stress - it feels like, if anything, it would increase it. (P335) Paying attention to how you think about stressful situations can help you feel better. Today, pay attention to your negative automatic thoughts as they arise, think about how you react to them and how you can begin to counter and reshape those thoughts into something more constructive. (P335)
Gratitude Fill in this note and put it somewhere you can see it. “I am grateful to _____ for _______.” The tone is vague. I also am unclear from this, what specifically I could write about and why I should. I want context. (P493) Even a little bit of gratitude can improve your day. Fill in this note and put it somewhere you can see it. “I am grateful to _____ for _______.” Writing it out will make it feel more real and concrete. (P493)
Positive Activities Schedule one pleasant thing to do tomorrow and pick a time to do it. nothing (P246) Tomorrow, take the time to do something that makes you happy. Set aside an hour and do this activity (P246)
Problem Solving Think about a simple problem you’d like to solve, then pick the solution that can help you resolve the problem effectively and with the fewest unintended consequences. Next, try it out! I think it might be an oversimplification. Attempting to stand and consider all the potentialities wrought by a single possible solution could be overwhelming in and of itself. (P171) Think about a simple problem you’d like to solve, then pick the solution that can help you resolve the problem. Next, try it out! Any effort toward a goal is a small victory! (P171)
Relationships Who’s the most cheerful person you know? Ask if they’d like to have coffee or some other kind of get together. Word it in a better way maybe, like “who usually makes your day? go talk to them.” (P387) Think about the person in your life that makes you the happiest most consistently. Make a point to spend more time with them! (P387)

Message Topics and Crowdsourced Example Messages

passage.infon:
Message Topic Brief Description Example Message (Crowdsourced)
Self-Care Messages that prompt you to take good care of yourself, indulge yourself, or be kind and compassionate to yourself Sometimes you just need a small amount of personal time. It’s okay to take that time for yourself.
Gratitudea Messages that prompt you to reflect on things you are grateful for, or to express gratitude Think of a person you are thankful for.
Thought Challenginga Messages that help you to identify unhelpful patterns of thinking and find new ways of thinking about things Today, spend some time thinking about how you react to things. If you react too negatively, try to change it to positive.
Inspiration Messages that convey hope and build excitement about possibilities to come Today is your day. Nothing can stop you.
Relaxation Messages that help you to calm down or gain a sense of wellbeing through exercises such as stretching, breathing, or mindfulnessb Stop and breathe for a minute. Take in your surroundings.
Problem Solvinga Messages that help you make and carry out plans to resolve issues Don’t run away from your problems. Break them down and tackle each step.
Positive Activitiesa Messages that prompt you to plan or engage in enjoyable activities Try to take a pleasure drive or a nature walk out in a park or forest to help lift your spirits.
Reassuring Messages that remind you that facing challenges is normal, and that things are going to be okay or that they are not as bad as they might seem It’s okay to feel overwhelmed.
Affirmation Messages that help you identify and acknowledge your strengths, abilities, and worth You’re amazing.
Relationshipsa Messages that help resolve conflicts and build stronger bonds with others in your life Focus more on connecting with good people around you.
Positive Thinking Messages that prompt you to focus on positive aspects of your experience Think about the things that have gone well in your life, and try to maintain a positive outlook.

Message topic was in the original expert-composed message set

While mindfulness and relaxation exercises are generally distinguished in the psychology literature, we combined them here to reflect that participants grouped these together in their topic suggestions and example messages
